facts.text: First information report (Ext. Ka-9) lodged by Kartar Singh s/o Shri Lachman Singh at police station Kotwali, Sub-District Nawabganj, District Barabanki on February 7, 1966.
Izhar Hussain (respondent, aged about 13 years) and some others tried before Additional District Magistrate (Judicial), Barabanki for offences under Sections 147, 323/149 and 325/149, IPC.

Santokh Singh (appellant) appeared as P.W.4 on September 3, 1966. In examination-in-chief: Identified Mohd. Zahir, Usman, Shahnshah, Puttan and Izhar Hussain in marpit and thereafter in identification parade in jail. In cross-examination: Did not see Izhar Hussain among assailants or that night; identified at instance of Octroi post people.
Kartar Singh and Santokh Singh stated they had not actually seen Izhar Hussain at place of occurrence.
Additional District Magistrate acquitted all accused on November 30, 1966. Did not hold Santokh Singh falsely charged Izhar Hussain or consider prosecution under S.211 IPC expedient.

Izhar Hussain filed application on January 11, 1967 before Additional District Magistrate under Ss.476/479A Cr.P.C. praying prosecution of Kartar Singh, Santokh Singh and R.D. Chowdhry S.I. under Ss.211/193 IPC. Rejected as incompetent per Kuppa Goundan case.
Appeal to Sessions Judge, Barabanki dismissed on March 15, 1967, applying bar of S.479A(6) Cr.P.C.

Revision to Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench under Ss.435/439 Cr.P.C. Allowed on May 22, 1969: Set aside lower orders, directed Deputy Registrar to file complaint under S.211 IPC against Santokh Singh for falsely charging Izhar Hussain.
Izhar Hussain's father in transport business had trade rivalry with Santokh Singh and his master.

legal_issues.text: Whether giving false evidence as a prosecution witness constitutes 'falsely charges' any person with having committed an offence under S.211 IPC.
Whether it is expedient in the interest of justice to direct filing of complaint under S.211 IPC against the appellant.
Whether High Court had jurisdiction to direct complaint under S.211 IPC when trial court and Sessions Judge declined.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant neither lodged FIR nor instituted criminal proceeding or falsely charged Izhar Hussain under S.211 IPC. No material on record to form opinion expedient in interest of justice to file complaint.
High Court direction based on misreading of evidence and erroneous view of law.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant's statement in witness box identifying Izhar Hussain constitutes false charge under S.211 IPC, as per Haridas v. State of West Bengal. Not prosecuting for perjury under S.479A CrPC, so no bar.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.211 IPC; Haridas v. State of West Bengal; Ss.195(1)(b), 476 CrPC

court_reasoning.text: Expression 'falsely charges' in S.211 IPC cannot mean giving false evidence as prosecution witness; refers to original accusation to set criminal law in motion, not deposition in support. False testimony falls under Ss.193/195 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Falsely charges' must be initial accusation to person in authority, embodied in complaint or FIR.

court_reasoning.text: No offence under S.211 IPC committed by appellant. Appellant admitted not seeing Izhar Hussain. Not expedient to prosecute; courts exercise discretion only in glaring cases of deliberate falsehood.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Every incorrect statement does not warrant prosecution; larger interest of administration of justice.

court_reasoning.text: High Court lacked jurisdiction to direct complaint; only trial court or subordinate court can. Should have remanded if error in lower courts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.195(3) CrPC; Kuldip Singh v. State of Punjab.

holdings.text: Testimony as witness identifying accused does not constitute 'falsely charges' under S.211 IPC.
Not expedient in interest of justice to file complaint under S.211 IPC against appellant.
High Court not justified in directing complaint; appeal allowed, High Court order set aside.

precedents_cited.relevance: Proceedings under S.476 CrPC incompetent if trial court did not proceed under S.479A despite finding perjury.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shabir Hussain Bholu v. State of Maharashtra
Haridas v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Words 'or falsely charges' in S.211 IPC not restricted to institution of proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kuldip Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Subordination of courts under S.195(3) CrPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged in original case; false charge of offence and giving false evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for complaints on offences affecting public justice; bar on perjury prosecution.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave allowed; order of Allahabad High Court dated May 22, 1969 set aside. No direction for filing complaint under S.211 IPC against appellant.

key_quotes.text: The expression 'falsely charges' in this section, in our opinion, cannot mean giving false evidence as a prosecution witness against an accused person during the course of a criminal trial.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing S.211 IPC from perjury offences.

key_quotes.text: Every incorrect or false statement does not make it incumbent on the court to order prosecution.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle on expediency in ordering prosecutions.
